com.thinkify.rfid
Class ThinkifyReader

java.lang.Object
  com.thinkify.rfid.ThinkifyReader
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.EventListener, javax.comm.SerialPortEventListener
public class ThinkifyReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements javax.comm.SerialPortEventListener

ThinkifyReader connects to a Thinkify RFID reader over a serial port, and handles the basic send, receive, send-receive functionality required to communicate with Thinkify readers.

Many convenience methods are provided, to abstract out many of the RFID details. For instance, to get the firmware version, call getVersion() and you will get a string-representation of the reader's response. To read the strongest tag in view of the reader, call find_strongest_tag() and you will get a ThinkifyTag back, which contains all of the details of the tag that was read. Use the setAutoMode(true/false) method to start and stop background tag-reading. In AutoMode, the reader will read tags and they will be collected by the API. Access the ThinkifyTaglist directly from the ThinkifyReader object (not very thread-safe at this point) to process the reads that are collected this way.

Of course, you could always use send_receive("t63") and parse the resulting list of tag data from the reader. Most of the other sundry reader commands must be executed this way.

Author:
David Krull

Field Detail

debugLevel

public int debugLevel
Control the amount of debugging output to see. Leaving debugLevel=0 allows only the basic application startup/shutdown and error messages. Setting debugLevel=1 enables top-level read/write logging, and higher values of debugLevel may offer even more granular logging of data.

taglist

public ThinkifyTaglist taglist
This is direct access to the internal ThinkifyTaglist. This list is used to accumulate tag data received in a streaming mode from the reader. It may not be a particularly thread-safe way to do things.

VERSION

public static final java.lang.String VERSION
Static String used to indicate the version number of this build of the API.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

ThinkifyReader

public ThinkifyReader(java.lang.String address)
Create an object representing a ThinkifyReader connected via a serial interface. The address of the reader, it's serial port name, is provided as the sole argument to this class's constructor.

The reader normally communicates at 115,200 baud. The accompanying SerialManager class is used to handle the details of the serial interface. There are also a static getAvailableSerialPorts() method for asking the JRE what serial port names are available. My reader shows up as "usbmodem411", which happens to be mounted at /dev/tty.usbmodem411.

Parameters:
address - the name of the serial port where the reader is connected

send

public void send(java.lang.String text)
          throws java.io.IOException
Sends a text string to the reader. The line terminator, is automatically appended to your command string.

Parameters:
text - the string to send to the reader
Throws:
java.io.IOException

receive

public java.lang.String receive(int timeoutMillis)
                         throws java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Waits for, and returns, a response from the reader. Exits with a TimeoutException if a complete response isn't received within timeoutMillis. A complete response from a reader always ends with the "READY>" prompt.

A timeout of 0 means "just take a peek", and a timeout of -1 means "wait forever".

Parameters:
timeoutMillis - maximum time to wait for the response
Returns:
the reader's response
Throws:
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException - if the response isn't received within the timeout

send_receive

public java.lang.String send_receive(java.lang.String cmd)
                              throws java.io.IOException,
                                     java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Sends the given cmd (also appending the line terminator before sending), and then waits for, and returns, the reader's entire response.

Parameters:
cmd - the text to send to the reader
Returns:
the reader's response
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

execute

public java.lang.String execute(java.lang.String cmd)
                         throws java.io.IOException,
                                java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Performs a send_receive() operation with the given cmd string, but parses the reader's reply, returning only the "value" part of the response (everything after the first =). This is useful for commands like "ra" (get RF attenuation), where you only want the numeric part of the response, and not the echoing-back of the parameter you are requesting.

Parameters:
cmd - the text to send to the reader
Returns:
the "value" portion of the reader's response
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

setLEDs

public void setLEDs(int ledState)
             throws java.io.IOException,
                    java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Set's the reader's four front LEDs to match the bit-map of the argument, ledState. The first bit of ledState corresponds to the first LED, the second bit corresponds to the 2nd LED, etc. all the way from 0 (no LEDs on) to 15 (all LEDs on).

Parameters:
ledState - the bit-map representing the desired state of the 4 LEDs
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

setAutoMode

public void setAutoMode(boolean onOffState)
                 throws java.io.IOException,
                        java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Turns on/off the APIs "automode" functionality. When AutoMode is turned on, the reader is set to run a continuous inventory, streaming tag data to the API. The API catched this asynchronous data from the reader, parses the tag info, and accumulates it in an internal ThinkifyTaglist.

Automode is interrupted by any call to execute() or send_receive(), but the API will restart Automode when those interruptions are finished. You can stop AutoMode by passing false to setAutoMode(), or by directly sending data to the reader with send().

Parameters:
onOffState - the new on/off state of AutoMode
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

getAutoMode

public boolean getAutoMode()
Returns the current on/off state of AutoMode.

Returns:
the current on/off state of AutoMode.

acquire

public ThinkifyTaglist acquire()
                        throws java.io.IOException,
                               java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Performs a quick scan of tags in the field (up to 3 of them), and returns a ThinkifyTaglist containing the data from the reads.

Returns:
a ThinkifyTaglist containing the data from the tags that were detected.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

find_strongest_tag

public ThinkifyTag find_strongest_tag()
                               throws java.io.IOException,
                                      java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
Performs a quick scan of tags in the field, and returns a ThinkifyTag with data on the strongest tag that was read (i.e. closer or better-presented to the antenna).

Returns:
a ThinkifyTag representing the strongest/closest tag to the reader
Throws:
java.io.IOException
java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException

serialEvent

public void serialEvent(javax.comm.SerialPortEvent serialEvent)
Called by the serial library when incoming data is available. This implements the SerialPortEventListener interface.

Specified by:
serialEvent in interface javax.comm.SerialPortEventListener

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
Main/test routine for ThinkifyReader. Opens a connection, prints the strongest tag, closes the connection, and exits. Connects to the serial port name given by the first command-line argument, or defaults to "usbmodem411" if no address is given.

Parameters:
args - the first arg can be the serial port name where the reader is connected
